Prune Info: No pruning necessary except to maintain desired shape.

Pruning is best done in late winter to early spring for most shrubs. With spring blooming shrubs prune after the blooms are spent. Remove up to 1/3rd of the overall shrub keeping older branches to build up a sturdy permanent and picturesque framework.

Trimming smoke trees can be done in late winter or very early spring when the plant is still mostly dormant. Summer flowering trees such as smoke trees need to be pruned before flower buds have shown.
Does not need frequent pruning. In fact unless desiring a more precise form simply remove dead and/or damaged stems during the end of summer/early fall.
Prune occasionally for a tidy appearance.
With spring blooming shrubs prune after the blooms are spent. Remove up to 1/3rd of the overall shrub.
Prune lightly in late winter or early spring to make a stronger and denser plant.
Prune either beginning of Fall or Spring.
Should be trimmed to the preferred size and shape in late winter or early spring before new growth emerges.
Prune occasionally for a tidy appearance.
You can prune Sunshine Ligustrum almost any time of the year. However if you're planning on pruning/trimming your plant wait until the threat of frost has passed in spring.
To maintain a size of 3-4' w x 3-4' h  Knock Out Roses should be cut back once a year to 12" high.
Shape in early spring before first flush.
The Patriot Hosta does not require much pruning but can benefit from the removal of dead or damaged leaves.
Cut plants back in early spring to encourage fresh new growth.
Should only be pruned right after it blooms.
You don't need to prune but pruning after they are done blooming can help encourage a bushier growth and renew an older plant.
Pruning is seldom needed but remove any dead wood or shape the plant immediately after flowering is complete for the season.

Prune Nikko after blooming because it flowers on old wood. Remove one-third of the old branches to maintain the arching shape and expose the center of the plant to more sunlight and better air circulation.
Cutting back the grass in late winter or early spring helps promote new growth and keeps the plant looking tidy.
Should be pruned in late winter or early spring before leafing out.
While this isn't necessary we recommend trimming your Pink Muhly Grass close to the ground in late winter or early spring after it goes dormant and browns.
Pruning should be done after the last frost.
Prune in spring to make room for new growth. Cut back dead stems completely. Prune diseased frost-damaged or dead shoots.
Requires little or no pruning. If you need to keep it smaller you can cut it soon after flowering.

Do not require fertilizer or regular pruning. Deadheading spent flower stalks will encourage new blooms on many types of coreopsis and prevent the plants from self-seeding. One way to accomplish this is to sheer large plantings in mid to late summer.
